text:
Allergies can cause serious injury. Just ask Billy Crystal.

The legendary comedian, 69, recently tore a rib muscle from sneezing.

“So I’m in that position that a lot of you young people find your parents in around 8:30,” Crystal told Jimmy Kimmel on Monday. “I’m in a position, like, only a Cirque du Soleil person or a jellyfish could be in. And out of the blue I sneezed, but a violent sneeze.”

He went on to describe the scenario as if he were an animated figure. “Folks, if it were a cartoon my arms are flying off my body, my eyes are coming out of my head, people in the room are now naked because I blew their clothes off,” Crystal quipped.

Soon after, he began to feel pain.

“I literally could not breathe,” he described. “And it’s not an injury you want to brag about. I didn’t rescue a woman out of a burning car. I didn’t catch an orphan falling out of a burning orphanage … I sneezed.”

“We have several muscles, which help the ribs move and help us breathe, namely internal intercostal muscles, external intercostal muscles, subcostalis muscle and the transverse thoracis muscle,” Jyoti Kini MD, primary care doctor at Medical Offices of Manhattan tells Page Six. “These muscles contract during sneezing and even coughing. Sudden violent movements or contractions of these muscles as seen with repeated sneezing can cause injury to these muscles…Treatment of these rib muscle sprains involves rest, ice and anti-inflammatory medications. If caused by sneezing anti-histamines might be helpful.”
title: Billy Crystal tore a rib muscle from sneezing
